summary: This is a declaration by FBI Section Chief Michael G. Seidel submitted in support of the FBI's motion for summary judgment in a FOIA lawsuit brought by Radar Online LLC and James Robertson. The declaration details the FBI's processing of a FOIA request for records related to the investigation and prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein, justifying the withholding of thousands of pages under various FOIA exemptions.

persons.name: Michael G. Seidel
persons.role: Section Chief of the Record/Information Dissemination Section (RIDS), FBI
persons.context: Author of the declaration, providing sworn testimony about the FBI's FOIA processing procedures and justification for withholding records related to Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the FOIA request. The declaration references his 2008 guilty plea, 2019 indictment, arrest, and death while in custody.

persons.name: James Robertson
persons.context: One of the plaintiffs who submitted the FOIA request seeking all documents relating to the FBI's investigation and prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein.

connections.description: Robertson is a plaintiff suing the FBI under FOIA to obtain records about the FBI's investigation and prosecution of Epstein.
Seidel, as an FBI Section Chief, supervised the processing of the FOIA request for records concerning the FBI's investigation of Epstein.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty to a state criminal charge of procuring prostitution of a minor and served 13 months of an 18-month sentence.

events.title: Epstein's Federal Indictment in SDNY
events.description: Epstein was indicted by a federal grand jury in the Southern District of New York on charges of conspiracy to commit sex trafficking and sex trafficking.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest on Federal Charges
events.description: Epstein was arrested by federal authorities based on the July 2, 2019 indictment.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Epstein died at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York while federal charges were pending.

events.title: Submission of FOIA Request
events.description: Plaintiff James Robertson submitted a FOIA request to the FBI seeking all documents relating to the FBI's investigation and prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein.

locations: Winchester, Virginia (Location of FBI's RIDS section)
Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (Where Epstein died)
Southern District of New York (Jurisdiction of Epstein's 2019 indictment and the FOIA lawsuit)
Southern District of Florida (Jurisdiction of a sealed court order referenced in the declaration)
keyFacts: The FBI processed 11,571 pages in response to the FOIA request for Epstein investigation records, releasing only 181 pages in full and 1,051 pages in part, while withholding 10,339 pages in full.

The FBI began asserting FOIA Exemption 7(A) to categorically withhold records after Epstein's arrest in July 2019, citing the need to protect ongoing law enforcement proceedings, including the investigation of potential co-conspirators.

The declaration details numerous FOIA exemptions used to withhold information, including protections for grand jury material, confidential sources, law enforcement techniques, and the personal privacy of third parties, victims, and government personnel.
38 pages were withheld in full because they are subject to a sealed court order from the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida.

The declaration reveals the FBI's internal processing methods, including the use of categorical review for records after Epstein's arrest and the migration of data from the Automated Case Support (ACS) system to the Sentinel case management system.
